span.span: Martin Schmaltz x𝑥FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{x} and Witold Skiba y𝑦FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-y FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{y}

x𝑥FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{x}SLAC, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94309
schmaltz@slac.stanford.edu

skiba@einstein.ucsd.edu

div.p: We propose Minimal Gaugino Mediation as the simplest known solution to the supersymmetric flavor and CP problems. The framework predicts a very minimal structure for the soft parameters at ultra-high energies: gaugino masses are unified and non-vanishing whereas all other soft supersymmetry breaking parameters vanish. We show that this boundary condition naturally arises from a small extra dimension and present a complete model which includes a new extra-dimensional solution to the μ𝜇italic-mu\mu problem. We briefly discuss the predicted superpartner spectrum as a function of the two parameters of the model. The commonly ignored renormalization group evolution above the GUT scale is crucial to the viability of Minimal Gaugino Mediation but does not introduce new model dependence.

Hidden sectors are an essential ingredient of simple and natural models of supersymmetry (SUSY) breaking. The unifying idea is that SUSY is assumed to be broken in the hidden sector and then communicated to the minimal supersymmetric standard model (MSSM) by messenger interactions which are flavor blind. This structure results in flavor-universal scalar masses and solves the SUSY flavor problem.

In the context of extra dimensions with branes such hidden sectors are very natural. If – for example – the MSSM and the SUSY breaking sector are confined to two different parallel 3-branes embedded in extra dimensions, then the separation in the extra dimensions forbids direct local couplings between the “visible” MSSM fields and the hidden sector. However, fields on separated branes can still communicate by exchanging bulk messenger fields. Couplings which arise from such non-local bulk mode exchange are suppressed. For a messenger of mass M𝑀italic-MM and brane separation L𝐿italic-LL the suppression factor is e-M⁢Lsuperscript𝑒𝑀𝐿italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-M italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ende^{-ML}, which is the Yukawa propagator of the messenger field exchanged between the two branes.

This suggest a very simple scenario for communicating SUSY breaking to the MSSM which guarantees flavor-universal scalar masses. If all light bulk fields have flavor blind couplings then the soft SUSY breaking parameters generated by exchange of these messengers preserve flavor. Heavy bulk modes may violate flavor maximally but the resulting non-universal contributions to the scalar masses are exponentially suppressed [1].

The two obvious candidates for bulk fields which can communicate SUSY breaking to the Standard Model fields in a flavor-blind way are gravity and the Standard Model gauge fields. Gravity as a bulk messenger (“Anomaly Mediation” [1, 2]) leads to a very simple and predictive model which unfortunately predicts negative slepton masses and is therefore ruled out in its simplest and most elegant form.***For models which cure Anomaly Mediation by introducing new fields and interactions see [3]. The alternative, Standard Model gauge fields as messengers (“Gaugino Mediation”), has been proposed recently by D.E. Kaplan, Kribs, and Schmaltz [4] as well as by Chacko, Luty, Nelson, and Ponton [5] and was found to work perfectly. In Gaugino Mediation the MSSM matter fields (quarks, leptons and superpartners) live on a “matter brane”, while SUSY breaks on a parallel “SUSY breaking brane”, and the MSSM gauge superfields live in the bulk. Because the gaugino fields are bulk fields they couple directly to the SUSY breaking and obtain soft masses. The MSSM scalars are separated from SUSY breaking by the distance L𝐿italic-LL and therefore obtain much smaller masses from non-local loops with high momentum modes of the bulk gauge fields [6, 4]. Thus at the compactification scale the theory matches onto a four-dimensional theory with gaugino masses and negligibly small scalar masses.

Vanishing scalar masses and non-vanishing gaugino masses at a high scale, as in no-scale models [7], is very attractive because evolving the theory to low energies via the renormalization group equation generates flavor-universal and positive soft scalar masses. Consistent electroweak symmetry breaking also requires a μ𝜇italic-mu\mu term of size comparable to the gaugino masses. Thus a minimal version of Gaugino Mediation has only three high energy parameters

div.p: Here M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} is the common gaugino mass at the unification scale, and Mcsubscript𝑀𝑐italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c} is the compactification scale where the higher dimensional theory is matched onto the effective four-dimensional theory. Since we wish to preserve the successful prediction of sin2⁡θwsuperscript2subscript𝜃𝑤TRIGFUNCTION:sine POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sin^{2}\theta_{w} from gauge coupling unification in the MSSM we limit Mc>MG⁢U⁢Tsubscript𝑀𝑐subscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c}>M_{GUT}.

In Section II of this paper we show that this scenario, which we call “Minimal Gaugino Mediation” (Mg̃M), with only the parameters in Eq. (1) works very well phenomenologically. The minimal scenario which we advocate here differs from the more general models in [4, 5] in that we do not introduce soft supersymmetry breaking mass parameters in the Higgs sector of the theory at Mcsubscript𝑀𝑐italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c}. Radiative electroweak symmetry breaking works automatically in Mg̃M and determines μ𝜇italic-mu\mu by fitting to the Z𝑍italic-ZZ mass. Therefore the entire superpartner spectrum of Mg̃M can be computed via the renormalization group equations in terms of only two free parameters: M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} and Mcsubscript𝑀𝑐italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c}. We will see that the running from Mcsubscript𝑀𝑐italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c} to MG⁢U⁢Tsubscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{GUT} in the grand unified theory is important for the masses of the lightest superpartners. We find that the Bino is the LSP and a perfect cold dark matter candidate in a large region of the models’ parameter space. “Minimal Gaugino Mediation” also evades all existing collider bounds without fine-tuning.

In Section III we present a complete and economical model which gives rise to the Mg̃M boundary condition. The model generates the hierarchy between the Planck scale and the SUSY breaking scale with the extra-dimensional dynamical supersymmetry breaking mechanism of Arkani-Hamed, Hall, Smith, and Weiner [8]. To solve the μ𝜇italic-mu\mu problem without introducing a B⁢μ𝐵𝜇italic-B italic-muB\mu problem we propose a new mechanism in which five-dimensional N=1𝑁1italic-N RELOP:equals NUMBER:1N=1 supersymmetry relates μ𝜇italic-mu\mu and the gaugino mass.
In Section IV we briefly explain why Mg̃M has no SUSY CP problem, estimate the neutralino relic density, and conclude.

In this section we determine the predictions of Mg̃M for the spectrum of MSSM particles. The input parameters of the model are listed in Eq. (1). We use the renormalization group equations (RGEs) of the DR¯¯DROVERACCENT:overline ARG:start DR ARG:end\overline{\rm DR} scheme to calculate the soft breaking parameters at the electroweak scale. We first outline our procedure for the running and discuss general features of the evolution. Then we present the spectrum of superparticles and describe how the experimental limits translate into constraints on the parameter space of the model.

div.p: We limit the range of compactification scales from below by the GUT scale in order to preserve the successful prediction of sin2⁡θwsuperscript2subscript𝜃𝑤TRIGFUNCTION:sine POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sin^{2}\theta_{w} from four dimensional unification in the MSSM. Note that this requirement would still allow compactification scales slightly below MG⁢U⁢Tsubscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{GUT}; however as we will discover below, Mcsubscript𝑀𝑐italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c} needs to be slightly larger than MG⁢U⁢Tsubscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{GUT} to avoid a charged LSP. The upper limit on Mcsubscript𝑀𝑐italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c} is more model dependent. It arises from demanding that flavor violating soft masses are sufficiently small. Such masses are generated from exchange of massive bulk fields with flavor-violating couplings, which are expected to be present in any fundamental theory which explains the Yukawa couplings of the Standard Model. Assuming that the lightest such states have masses of order MP⁢l⁢a⁢n⁢c⁢ksubscript𝑀𝑃𝑙𝑎𝑛𝑐𝑘italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P italic-l italic-a italic-n italic-c italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{Planck} the suppression factor is of the order of exp⁡(-MP⁢l⁢a⁢n⁢c⁢k/Mc)subscript𝑀𝑃𝑙𝑎𝑛𝑐𝑘subscript𝑀𝑐OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P italic-l italic-a italic-n italic-c italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\exp(-M_{Planck}/M_{c}). Requiring that this exponential suppresses off-diagonal squark masses sufficiently gives Mc<∼MP⁢l⁢a⁢n⁢c⁢k/10fragmentsfragmentssimilar-tosubscript𝑀𝑐subscript𝑀𝑃𝑙𝑎𝑛𝑐𝑘10italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:start ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:less-than CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:similar-to CELL:end ROW:end RELOP:end italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P italic-l italic-a italic-n italic-c italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:10{{{{M_{c}\mathrel{\mathchoice{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$\displaystyle\hfill<$% \cr$\displaystyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$\textstyle% \hfill<$\cr$\textstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$% \scriptstyle\hfill<$\cr$\scriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{% \cr}$\scriptscriptstyle\hfill<$\cr$\scriptscriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}}M_{Planck}% /10.

To connect the boundary condition of Eq. (2) to experiments at the weak scale we first run from Mcsubscript𝑀𝑐italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c} to MG⁢U⁢Tsubscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{GUT} in the unified theory and then run from MG⁢U⁢Tsubscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{GUT} to the weak scale with the RGEs of the MSSM. Gaugino domination, or the no-scale, boundary conditions have been studied extensively in the literature, however only including renormalization below the GUT scale [9, 10, 11]. Since the renormalization effects above the GUT scale are not discussed very frequently in the literature we describe them in some detail first.

Naively, one might be tempted to argue against calculating renormalization effects above the GUT scale because: i. the running above the GUT scale gives only very small masses because log⁡(McMG⁢U⁢T)≪log⁡(MG⁢U⁢TMw⁢e⁢a⁢k)much-less-thansubscript𝑀𝑐subscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇subscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇subscript𝑀𝑤𝑒𝑎𝑘OPFUNCTION:logarithm OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) RELOP:much-less-than OPFUNCTION:logarithm OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-w italic-e italic-a italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:)\log(\frac{M_{c}}{M_{GUT}})\ll\log(\frac{M_{GUT}}{M_{weak}}) and ii. the running of soft masses above the GUT scale is model dependent because the theory above the GUT scale contains new unknown fields and couplings which enter the RGEs and give rise to unknown threshold effects. Both of these arguments are invalid as is easy to see: Argument i. neglects group theory factors. For example, the mass which is generated for the right-handed sleptons from running below the GUT scale is very small because they only couple to hypercharge. Above the GUT scale, sleptons are unified into larger GUT representations and the associated larger multiplicity factors more then compensate for the smaller log. The second argument would apply in general theories with soft masses, but it does not apply to Mg̃M where (at one loop) all generated soft masses are determined by gauge charges only. To understand this consider a generic one-loop RG equation for scalar soft terms

div.p: Here the first term is determined entirely by the known gauge charges, whereas the second term depends on unknown new fields and couplings. However, in Mg̃M all soft terms for the scalars are zero at Mcsubscript𝑀𝑐italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c}. Therefore, the soft masses appearing in the second term are small (loop-suppressed compared to M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2}), and it is a good approximation to drop the second term. The only remaining model dependence is in the gauge interactions above the GUT scale. The predictions depend on the choice of unified gauge group, and we present predictions for both S⁢U⁢(5)𝑆𝑈5italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:5 CLOSE:)SU(5) and S⁢O⁢(10)𝑆𝑂10italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:10 CLOSE:)SO(10). Furthermore, there is also a weak dependence on the running of the unified gauge coupling above the GUT scale. We perform our renormalization group analysis assuming a minimal set of GUT representations (3×(10+5¯)+5+5¯+24310¯55¯524NUMBER:3 MULOP:times OPEN:( NUMBER:10 ADDOP:plus OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start NUMBER:5 ARG:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus NUMBER:5 ADDOP:plus OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start NUMBER:5 ARG:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:243\times(10+\bar{5})+5+\bar{5}+24 for the case of S⁢U⁢(5)𝑆𝑈5italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:5 CLOSE:)SU(5) and 3×16+10+45+16+1¯⁢6316104516¯16NUMBER:3 MULOP:times NUMBER:16 ADDOP:plus NUMBER:10 ADDOP:plus NUMBER:45 ADDOP:plus NUMBER:16 ADDOP:plus OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end NUMBER:63\times 16+10+45+16+\bar{1}6 for S⁢O⁢(10)𝑆𝑂10italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:10 CLOSE:)SO(10)). However, even adding as much as three additional adjoints to either theory would change the final scalar masses by at most a few percent.†††A more detailed discussion of RGEs above the GUT scale can be found in [12]. Finally, note that GUT threshold corrections to the supersymmetry breaking scalar masses vanish in DR¯¯DROVERACCENT:overline ARG:start DR ARG:end\overline{\rm DR} so that using the RGEs gives the complete answer.

Even though we perform our renormalization group analysis numerically one can also obtain extremely simple approximate formulae for the soft parameters at the GUT scale as follows. At one loop the ratio M1/2g2subscript𝑀12superscript𝑔2FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end\frac{M_{1/2}}{g^{2}} is RGE invariant. Thus, the running of M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} is trivial as it traces the running of the gauge coupling, and we present our results using α𝛼italic-alpha\alpha and M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} evaluated at MG⁢U⁢Tsubscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{GUT} rather than at Mcsubscript𝑀𝑐italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c}. Assuming that the running of the couplings above the GUT scale is not too fast all other soft terms at the GUT scale are then given by [13]

The first set of numbers in parenthesis applies to S⁢U⁢(5)𝑆𝑈5italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:5 CLOSE:)SU(5), the second one to S⁢O⁢(10)𝑆𝑂10italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:10 CLOSE:)SO(10). With an abuse of notation for the case of S⁢O⁢(10)𝑆𝑂10italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:10 CLOSE:)SO(10) we defined m𝟓¯2subscriptsuperscript𝑚2¯5italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start NUMBER:bold-5 ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm^{2}_{\bf\bar{5}} to denote the soft mass for the Higgses of the MSSM, while m𝟏𝟎2subscriptsuperscript𝑚210italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:bold-10 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm^{2}_{\bf 10} denotes the common soft mass of the matter fields.

Below the GUT scale we integrate the one-loop RGEs [14] numerically. One loop-running has adequate precision if one uses the one-loop improved Higgs potential [15, 16]. The dominant correction to the lightest Higgs mass comes from top quark loops below the stop mass threshold. It can be accounted for by adding the term

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t italic-o italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:16 italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end OPFUNCTION:logarithm FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-t ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-t ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end OPEN:( italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.

div.p: In addition, we incorporate the contributions to squark and slepton masses arising from D-terms as described in Ref. [10].

After evolving all soft masses to the weak scale we impose the constraints which follow from radiative electroweak symmetry breaking. This determines the weak scale values of both μ𝜇italic-mu\mu and tan⁡β𝛽TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta\tan\beta, and we are left with only two free parameters: M1/2⁢(MG⁢U⁢T)subscript𝑀12subscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)M_{1/2}(M_{GUT}) and the compactification scale Mcsubscript𝑀𝑐italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c}. The μ𝜇italic-mu\mu parameter is multiplicatively renormalized, and it does not enter any RGE at one loop. Therefore, we will quote its value at the weak scale.

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: The dependence of the masses of the stau, the lightest neutralino and the lightest Higgs on the compactification scale for fixed M1/2=250subscript𝑀12250italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:250M_{1/2}=250 GeV. The neutralino mass (104104NUMBER:104104 GeV) and the Higgs mass (111111NUMBER:111111 GeV) are almost independent of the compactification scale and the GUT gauge group. The rising solid line and the dashed line indicate the mass of the stau in S⁢U⁢(5)𝑆𝑈5italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:5 CLOSE:)SU(5) and S⁢O⁢(10)𝑆𝑂10italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:10 CLOSE:)SO(10), respectively.

div.p: Figure 1 illustrates the significance of the RG evolution above the GUT scale. Without running above the GUT scale (Mc=MG⁢U⁢Tsubscript𝑀𝑐subscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c}=M_{GUT}) the stau is the LSP; however for any compactification scale larger than only 1.5⁢MG⁢U⁢T1.5subscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇NUMBER:1.5 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end1.5M_{GUT} the stau is heavier than the lightest neutralino. Note that the dependence of the stau mass on tc=log⁡(McMG⁢U⁢T)subscript𝑡𝑐subscript𝑀𝑐subscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPFUNCTION:logarithm OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:)t_{c}=\log(\frac{M_{c}}{M_{GUT}}) is stronger in S⁢O⁢(10)𝑆𝑂10italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:10 CLOSE:)SO(10) than in S⁢U⁢(5)𝑆𝑈5italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:5 CLOSE:)SU(5). This follows from the larger group theoretical factors in S⁢O⁢(10)𝑆𝑂10italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:10 CLOSE:)SO(10) which cause soft masses above the GUT scale to be generated more efficiently.

The allowed parameter space for S⁢U⁢(5)𝑆𝑈5italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:5 CLOSE:)SU(5) and S⁢O⁢(10)𝑆𝑂10italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:10 CLOSE:)SO(10) Mg̃M models is presented in Figure 2. We find a lower bound on tcsubscript𝑡𝑐italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{c} from requiring that the LSP be neutral. An upper bound on tcsubscript𝑡𝑐italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{c} is not shown on the figure, but as discussed above, flavor violating effects due to massive bulk fields limit tc≲4less-than-or-similar-tosubscript𝑡𝑐4italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:4t_{c}\mathrel{\lesssim}4. Since M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} is the only source for superpartner masses, the experimental lower limits on superpartner masses and the Higgs mass translate into lower limits on M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2}. In particular, we find that the LEP II limits [17] on the Higgs mass (mho≥subscript𝑚superscriptℎ𝑜absentitalic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-equalsm_{h^{o}}\geq 106 GeV)‡‡‡The Standard Model Higgs bound rather than the much weaker SUSY Higgs bound applies in the entire allowed parameter space because μ𝜇italic-mu\mu is sufficiently large so that the heavier Higgs fields decouple and the production cross section becomes Standard-Model-like. and the right handed slepton masses (mτ~≥75subscript𝑚~𝜏75italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-tau ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:75m_{\tilde{\tau}}\geq 75 GeV and me~≥95subscript𝑚~𝑒95italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-e ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:95m_{\tilde{e}}\geq 95 GeV) imply M1/2>∼180fragmentsfragmentssimilar-tosubscript𝑀12180italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:start ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:greater-than CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:similar-to CELL:end ROW:end RELOP:end NUMBER:180{{{{M_{1/2}\mathrel{\mathrel{\mathchoice{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$% \displaystyle\hfill>$\cr$\displaystyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign% {\cr}$\textstyle\hfill>$\cr$\textstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign% {\cr}$\scriptstyle\hfill>$\cr$\scriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{% \halign{\cr}$\scriptscriptstyle\hfill>$\cr$\scriptscriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}}}180 GeV. Furthermore, we find that the μ𝜇italic-mu\mu parameter in our model is given by μ=3/2⁢M1/2𝜇32subscript𝑀12italic-mu RELOP:equals NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu=3/2M_{1/2} to an accuracy of better than 2%percentPOSTFIX:percent\% for all values of tcsubscript𝑡𝑐italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{c}. This implies a lower bound μ>∼270fragmentsfragmentssimilar-to𝜇270italic-mu RELOP:start ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:greater-than CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:similar-to CELL:end ROW:end RELOP:end NUMBER:270{{{{\mu\mathrel{\mathrel{\mathchoice{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$\displaystyle% \hfill>$\cr$\displaystyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$% \textstyle\hfill>$\cr$\textstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$% \scriptstyle\hfill>$\cr$\scriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{% \cr}$\scriptscriptstyle\hfill>$\cr$\scriptscriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}}}270 GeV with an associated mild tuning of the Z𝑍italic-ZZ mass.

figure.figcaption: Figure 2: The allowed region of the parameter space for Mg̃M with S⁢U⁢(5)𝑆𝑈5italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:5 CLOSE:)SU(5) and S⁢O⁢(10)𝑆𝑂10italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:10 CLOSE:)SO(10) unified group. The curves at the bottom of the figure correspond to LEP II limits on the masses of the Higgs (more restrictive) and stau (less restrictive). Demanding that relic LSPs contribute the cosmologically preferred amount of cold dark matter and do not over-close the universe singles out the region of parameter space between the lines labeled Ω⁢h2=0.1Ωsuperscriptℎ20.1Omega italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1\Omega h^{2}=0.1 and 0.30.3NUMBER:0.30.3.

div.p: The figure also shows contours of the relic abundance of the lightest neutralino corresponding to Ωχ⁢h2=0.1, 0.3subscriptΩ𝜒superscriptℎ20.1 0.3Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-chi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0.3\Omega_{\chi}h^{2}=0.1,\ 0.3. The LSP relic abundance calculation is particularly simple in our model, we discuss it briefly in Section IV.

figure.figcaption: Figure 3: Left graph: particle masses as functions of M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} for fixed compactification scale. The lines correspond to (from lightest to heaviest at M1/2=600subscript𝑀12600italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:600M_{1/2}=600 GeV) the lightest Higgs, lightest neutralino, right-handed stau, second lightest neutralino, heavy chargino, pseudoscalar Higgs, left-handed stop, and gluino. Right graph: contours of constant tan⁡β𝛽TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta\tan\beta. The contours correspond to tan⁡β𝛽TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta\tan\beta of 9, 12, 15, 18, and 21 from left to right. The solid lines are for S⁢U⁢(5)𝑆𝑈5italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:5 CLOSE:)SU(5), the dashed ones for S⁢O⁢(10)𝑆𝑂10italic-S italic-O OPEN:( NUMBER:10 CLOSE:)SO(10).

div.p: Figure 3 shows the Mg̃M spectrum as a function of the gaugino mass for the example case of an S⁢U⁢(5)𝑆𝑈5italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:5 CLOSE:)SU(5) GUT with log⁡(McMG⁢U⁢T)=2subscript𝑀𝑐subscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇2OPFUNCTION:logarithm OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:2\log(\frac{M_{c}}{M_{GUT}})=2. The qualitative features of the spectrum are generic and do not depend on the choice of grand unified group or compactification scale. The masses of all superpartners and Higgs fields, except for the lightest Higgs, rise linearly with M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2}. As in minimal supergravity the LSP is a Bino-like neutralino. The right-handed stau is the next-to-LSP. As usual, colored superpartners are heaviest, followed by charginos, neutralinos and Higgses with masses of order μ𝜇italic-mu\mu. The mass of the lightest Higgs particle increases only logarithmically with M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} through the one-loop improvement of the Higgs potential as described in Eq. (9).

Figure 3 also shows contours of constant tan⁡β𝛽TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta\tan\beta in the M1/2-tcsubscript𝑀12subscript𝑡𝑐italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2}-t_{c} plane. Note that in the allowed region tan⁡β𝛽TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta\tan\beta is almost independent of M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2}, but it increases with tcsubscript𝑡𝑐italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{c}.

Since Mg̃M has only 2 free parameters, measuring the masses of only two particles is in principle sufficient to determine the input parameters and predict the entire superpartner spectrum. In practice, presumably the Higgs will be the first new particle to be discovered. This is because the MSSM Higgs mass bound of 130 GeV applies also to the Mg̃M Higgs which could therefore be discovered (or ruled out) at Run II of the Tevatron [18], and might even be seen at LEP 205. The mass of the Higgs would give an estimate of M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2}. Should M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} be close to 200 GeV, there is a chance that LEP or the Tevatron will discover the first superpartners. For low enough compactification scales LEP would find the right-handed stau and/or selectron. Independent of the compactification scale the Tevatron could then observe charginos in the tri-lepton channel [19]. For larger M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} we would have to wait for the LHC.

It is exciting that observation of the first superpartner immediately also leads to a first test of the model. This is because the discovery would allow a mass measurement of both the discovered superpartner as well as the LSP mass from the distribution of the missing energy. One could then use the measured masses of the Higgs and Bino to obtain two independent determinations of M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} and therefore test the model. Once we know a mass of any of the sleptons we can extract the remaining free parameter – tcsubscript𝑡𝑐italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{c}. Note that discovery of just a few of the lightest superpartners would already allow a determination of the GUT gauge group!

In this section we describe a simple model which breaks supersymmetry and yields only gaugino masses at the compactification scale. Our model is complete: it generates exponentially small supersymmetry breaking which is mediated to the gauginos via a higher dimensional operator, and μ𝜇italic-mu\mu is naturally of the same order as the gaugino masses. The model combines the idea of “gaugino mediation” with the supersymmetry breaking mechanism proposed in [8].

To begin we recall the higher dimensional set-up of [4]. The MSSM matter and Higgs fields live on a 3+1 dimensional brane embedded in one extra dimension. Supersymmetry is broken dynamically on a parallel brane which is a distance L𝐿italic-LL apart from the matter brane (Fig. 4). The MSSM gauge fields and gauginos live in the bulk of the extra dimension. We take this extra dimension to be circular, with radius R𝑅italic-RR. In order to preserve the quantitative prediction of sin2⁡θwsuperscript2subscript𝜃𝑤TRIGFUNCTION:sine POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sin^{2}\theta_{w} from gauge coupling unification in the four dimensional MSSM, we demand that the compactification scale be higher than the GUT scale, R-1≡Mc≥MG⁢U⁢Tsuperscript𝑅1subscript𝑀𝑐subscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-equals italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR^{-1}\equiv M_{c}\geq M_{GUT}.§§§A similar constraint on the compactification scale also follows from demanding that the extra-dimensional theory remains perturbative up to the five dimensional Planck scale M𝑀italic-MM, gG⁢U⁢T2=g522⁢π⁢R<24⁢π5/22⁢π⁢R⁢Msuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝐺𝑈𝑇2superscriptsubscript𝑔522𝜋𝑅24superscript𝜋522𝜋𝑅𝑀italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-R ARG:end RELOP:less-than FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:24 italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-R italic-M ARG:endg_{GUT}^{2}={g_{5}^{2}\over 2\pi R}<{24\pi^{5/2}\over 2\pi RM}. Using 2⁢π⁢R⁢M3=MP⁢l⁢a⁢n⁢c⁢k22𝜋𝑅superscript𝑀3superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑃𝑙𝑎𝑛𝑐𝑘2NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-R italic-M POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P italic-l italic-a italic-n italic-c italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end2\pi RM^{3}=M_{Planck}^{2} this becomes R⁢MP⁢l⁢a⁢n⁢c⁢k<750𝑅subscript𝑀𝑃𝑙𝑎𝑛𝑐𝑘750italic-R italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P italic-l italic-a italic-n italic-c italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:750RM_{Planck}<750.

figure.figcaption: Figure 4: A brane configuration which leads to the Minimal Gaugino Mediation boundary condition. Pictured is the extra dimension from left to right with periodic boundary conditions. We also show the exponentially decaying vacuum expectation values of ϕitalic-ϕitalic-phi\phi and ϕcsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑐italic-phi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\phi^{c} which are responsible for generating hierarchically small supersymmetry breaking and the μ𝜇italic-mu\mu term.

div.p: In our model, supersymmetry breaking manifests itself in a vacuum expectation value for the F-component, XFsubscript𝑋𝐹italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{F}, of a chiral superfield X𝑋italic-XX on the SUSY breaking brane. The MSSM gaugino fields can couple to X𝑋italic-XX directly, giving a gaugino mass

semantics.annotation: INTOP:integral italic-d italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-delta OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-L CLOSE:) INTOP:integral italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-X italic-W italic-W ARG:end ARG:start italic-M POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARROW:rightarrow FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-V italic-M POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end italic-lambda italic-lambda PERIOD:.

div.p: Here, the factor of the extra-dimensional volume (V=2⁢π⁢R𝑉2𝜋𝑅italic-V RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-RV=2\pi R for a circle) arises from the wave function normalizations of the four-dimensional gaugino fields λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda. All other soft supersymmetry breaking parameters in the MSSM, such as soft scalar masses X†⁢X⁢Q†⁢Qsuperscript𝑋†𝑋superscript𝑄†𝑄italic-X POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-X italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-QX^{\dagger}XQ^{\dagger}Q, are suppressed at short distances by extra-dimensional locality [4]. The low-energy values of these parameters are generated from the renormalization group equations as discussed in the previous section.

It is useful to discuss the exact form of the short-distance suppressions in more detail. In general, there are two possible sources for such terms: direct contact terms suppressed by the cut-off M𝑀italic-MM or non-local terms from loops of the light bulk gauge fields. The contact terms are not present in the effective theory below M𝑀italic-MM to all orders in the local expansion in inverse powers of M𝑀italic-MM because they connect fields at different positions. However, this does not preclude the appearance of terms with coefficients e-L⁢Msuperscript𝑒𝐿𝑀italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-L italic-M POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ende^{-LM} which do not have an expansion in local operators. These operators are expected to be flavor violating and are therefore strongly constrained experimentally [20]. The most stringent constraint comes from CP violation in the K system and gives roughly e-L⁢M<∼10-4fragmentsfragmentssimilar-tosuperscript𝑒𝐿𝑀superscript104italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-L italic-M POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:start ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:less-than CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:similar-to CELL:end ROW:end RELOP:end NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{{{e^{-LM}\mathrel{\mathchoice{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$\displaystyle\hfill% <$\cr$\displaystyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$\textstyle% \hfill<$\cr$\textstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$% \scriptstyle\hfill<$\cr$\scriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{% \cr}$\scriptscriptstyle\hfill<$\cr$\scriptscriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}}10^{-4} or L⁢M>∼8fragmentsfragmentssimilar-to𝐿𝑀8italic-L italic-M RELOP:start ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:greater-than CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:similar-to CELL:end ROW:end RELOP:end NUMBER:8{{{{LM\mathrel{\mathchoice{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$\displaystyle\hfill>$\cr% $\displaystyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$\textstyle\hfill>$% \cr$\textstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$\scriptstyle\hfill% >$\cr$\scriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$% \scriptscriptstyle\hfill>$\cr$\scriptscriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}}8. Therefore, the allowed range for the compactification scale is MG⁢U⁢T<∼Mc<∼MP⁢l⁢a⁢n⁢c⁢k/10fragmentsfragmentssimilar-tosubscript𝑀𝐺𝑈𝑇subscript𝑀𝑐fragmentsfragmentssimilar-tosubscript𝑀𝑃𝑙𝑎𝑛𝑐𝑘10italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-U italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:start ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:less-than CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:similar-to CELL:end ROW:end RELOP:end italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:start ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:less-than CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start RELOP:similar-to CELL:end ROW:end RELOP:end italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P italic-l italic-a italic-n italic-c italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:10{{{{{{{{M_{GUT}\mathrel{\mathchoice{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$\displaystyle\hfill% <$\cr$\displaystyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$\textstyle% \hfill<$\cr$\textstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$% \scriptstyle\hfill<$\cr$\scriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{% \cr}$\scriptscriptstyle\hfill<$\cr$\scriptscriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}}M_{c}% \mathrel{\mathchoice{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$\displaystyle\hfill<$\cr$% \displaystyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$\textstyle\hfill<$% \cr$\textstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$\scriptstyle\hfill% <$\cr$\scriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}{\lower 3.0pt\vbox{\halign{\cr}$% \scriptscriptstyle\hfill<$\cr$\scriptscriptstyle\hfill\sim$}}}}M_{Planck}/10.

The other source of short-distance scalar masses – loops of bulk gauge fields – leads to finite contributions to the masses which are suppressed by additional powers of the separation L𝐿italic-LL relative to the gaugino mass (10). However, they are flavor universal because they arise from gauge interactions. As discussed in detail in [4] these contributions are negligible compared to the much larger contributions from the renormalization group evolution.

In the following Subsections we turn to discussing the mechanism of supersymmetry breaking and the origin of the μ𝜇italic-mu\mu term in the model. Our mechanism for breaking supersymmetry and stabilizing the radius of the extra dimension is taken directly from the elegant paper of Arkani-Hamed et. al. [8]. In the following, we summarize their discussion and apply it to our model. Our solution to the μ𝜇italic-mu\mu problem is new.

Following [8], we keep track of four-dimensional N=1𝑁1italic-N RELOP:equals NUMBER:1N=1 supersymmetry by employing four-dimensional N=1𝑁1italic-N RELOP:equals NUMBER:1N=1 superspace notation and treating the x5subscript𝑥5italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endx_{5} coordinate as a label. The action for a massive five-dimensional hypermultiplet (Φ,Φc)ΦsuperscriptΦ𝑐OPEN:( Phi PUNCT:, Phi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(\Phi,\Phi^{c}) then reads

div.p: The advantage of this formalism is that it is straightforward to write down N=1𝑁1italic-N RELOP:equals NUMBER:1N=1 supersymmetric couplings of ΦΦPhi\Phi to boundary fields. The supersymmetry breaking model of [8] consists of the bulk field ΦΦPhi\Phi with superpotential couplings to a source J𝐽italic-JJ and a field X𝑋italic-XX which are localized on different branes. J𝐽italic-JJ is localized on the matter brane at x5=0subscript𝑥50italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x_{5}=0, while X𝑋italic-XX on the SUSY-breaking brane at x5=Lsubscript𝑥5𝐿italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-Lx_{5}=L

div.p: Thus the source J𝐽italic-JJ “shines” a vacuum expectation value for the bulk scalar ϕitalic-ϕitalic-phi\phi which decays exponentially with increasing x5subscript𝑥5italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endx_{5} (see Fig. 4). Supersymmetry is broken because X𝑋italic-XX obtains a non-vanishing F𝐹italic-FF-component

div.p: Assuming a source J∼Msimilar-to𝐽𝑀italic-J RELOP:similar-to italic-MJ\sim M and a mass m∼Msimilar-to𝑚𝑀italic-m RELOP:similar-to italic-Mm\sim M one finds XF∼M2⁢e-M⁢Lsimilar-tosubscript𝑋𝐹superscript𝑀2superscript𝑒𝑀𝐿italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to italic-M POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-M italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{F}\sim M^{2}\ e^{-ML}.

Note that this model is a higher dimensional generalization of a simple O’Raifeartaigh model. The source J𝐽italic-JJ forces a non-zero expectation value for the field ϕitalic-ϕitalic-phi\phi, that is in conflict with the X𝑋italic-XX equation of motion which requires ϕ=0italic-ϕ0italic-phi RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\phi=0. The role of the extra dimension is to modulate the resulting supersymmetry breaking by the factor e-M⁢Lsuperscript𝑒𝑀𝐿italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-M italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ende^{-ML}. Coupling the field X𝑋italic-XX to the gauge fields as in Eq. (10) then results in non-vanishing gaugino masses

semantics.annotation: italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-R italic-M POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end RELOP:similar-to FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-J ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-R italic-M ARG:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-M italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.

div.p: As in ordinary O’Raifeartaigh models, the scalar expectation value of X𝑋italic-XX is undetermined classically. A non-vanishing expectation value can be seen to act as a source for ΦcsuperscriptΦ𝑐Phi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Phi^{c} from Eq. (13). In order to simplify the analysis we assume that the X𝑋italic-XX-expectation value is zero. This may either be enforced by additional tree-level superpotential terms on the supersymmetry breaking brane such as δ⁢(x5-L)⁢[X⁢Y+Y2⁢Z]𝛿subscript𝑥5𝐿delimited-[]𝑋𝑌superscript𝑌2𝑍italic-delta OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-L CLOSE:) OPEN:[ italic-X italic-Y ADDOP:plus italic-Y POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-Z CLOSE:]\delta(x_{5}-L)[XY+Y^{2}Z], or it could be a result of quantum corrections lifting the flat direction.

To generate a μ𝜇italic-mu\mu term of the correct size we utilize the ϕcsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑐italic-phi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\phi^{c} component of the superfield (Φ,Φc)ΦsuperscriptΦ𝑐OPEN:( Phi PUNCT:, Phi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(\Phi,\Phi^{c}). To break supersymmetry we used an expectation value for ϕitalic-ϕitalic-phi\phi which was “shining” clockwise from the source J𝐽italic-JJ on the matter brane towards the supersymmetry breaking brane. For generating μ𝜇italic-mu\mu we “shine” an expectation value for ϕcsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑐italic-phi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\phi^{c} by adding the superpotential

We see that the ϕitalic-ϕitalic-phi\phi equation is unchanged, while the new source Jcsuperscript𝐽𝑐italic-J POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endJ^{c} also “shines” an expectation value for ϕcsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑐italic-phi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\phi^{c}

div.p: Comparing this to the gaugino mass Eq. (17) we find that we need to set κ∼1/(2⁢π⁢R⁢M)∼1/100similar-to𝜅12𝜋𝑅𝑀similar-to1100italic-kappa RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-R italic-M CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:100\kappa\sim 1/(2\pi RM)\sim 1/100.

Note that μ𝜇italic-mu\mu has the exact same exponential suppression factor e-m⁢Lsuperscript𝑒𝑚𝐿italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-m italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ende^{-mL} as m1/2subscript𝑚12italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{1/2}. This follows from the fact that ϕitalic-ϕitalic-phi\phi and ϕcsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝑐italic-phi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\phi^{c} reside in the same five dimensional supersymmetry multiplet. In other words, five dimensional supersymmetry relates the exponential suppression factors appearing in μ𝜇italic-mu\mu and M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2}. It is disappointing that because of the volume suppression in the gaugino masses we still need to choose a small coupling κ𝜅italic-kappa\kappa to get μ∼M1/2similar-to𝜇subscript𝑀12italic-mu RELOP:similar-to italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu\sim M_{1/2}. However, κ𝜅italic-kappa\kappa is a superpotential coupling and as such can be small naturally. Note that the spatial separation of the supersymmetry breaking XFsubscript𝑋𝐹italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{F} from the location of the Higgs fields does not allow a B⁢μ𝐵𝜇italic-B italic-muB\mu term at the high scale. We therefore do not have the usual problem B∼16⁢π⁢μsimilar-to𝐵16𝜋𝜇italic-B RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:16 italic-pi italic-muB\sim 16\pi\mu which haunts most other approaches to the μ𝜇italic-mu\mu problem. Finally, we emphasize that this new extra-dimensional solution to the μ𝜇italic-mu\mu problem does have broader applicability.

In the discussion above we have assumed that the radius R𝑅italic-RR of the extra dimension and the distance L𝐿italic-LL between the branes are fixed. In a complete theory both parameters correspond to fields. We now discuss a simple supersymmetry-preserving mechanism to stabilize both R𝑅italic-RR and L𝐿italic-LL. Our mechanism is a trivial modification of [8]. In its simplest form it requires a single additional massive bulk hypermultiplet (Ψ,Ψc)ΨsuperscriptΨ𝑐OPEN:( Psi PUNCT:, Psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(\Psi,\Psi^{c}) with couplings to brane fields

div.p: Thus, for I𝐼italic-II and ΛΛLambda\Lambda of order M𝑀italic-MM a radius of the desired size is generated by choosing a relatively small mass for the bulk scalar mΨ∼M/30similar-tosubscript𝑚Ψ𝑀30italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to italic-M MULOP:divide NUMBER:30m_{\Psi}\sim M/30.
Minimal Gaugino Mediation is a very compelling and predictive theoretical framework which solves all supersymmetric naturalness problems without fine-tuning.

Mg̃M solves the supersymmetric flavor problem: At the high scale Mcsubscript𝑀𝑐italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{c} the scalar masses and A-terms vanish, and therefore the only flavor violation in renormalizable couplings resides in the Yukawa couplings. Gaugino loops generate universal positive scalar masses at low energies. Small non-universalities in the masses arise from the Yukawa interactions, but these contributions do not lead to new flavor violation because they are aligned with the Yukawa matrices. An exception to this is the running of the scalar masses above the GUT scale where flavor is broken by unified interactions [13, 21]. Since the right-handed sleptons are light in Mg̃M event rates for lepton flavor violating processes such as μ→e⁢γ→𝜇𝑒𝛾italic-mu ARROW:rightarrow italic-e italic-gamma\mu\rightarrow e\gamma might be near the experimental bounds.

Mg̃M solves the supersymmetric CP problem: This is easy to understand by realizing that at the compactification scale (where m2=A=B=0superscript𝑚2𝐴𝐵0italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-A RELOP:equals italic-B RELOP:equals NUMBER:0m^{2}=A=B=0) the phases in M1/2subscript𝑀12italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{1/2} and μ𝜇italic-mu\mu can be removed by phase redefinitions of the gaugino fields and the Higgs superfields, respectively. Therefore, the theory has no new phases beyond the phases in the Yukawa couplings and no supersymmetric CP violation. This does not solve the strong CP problem however.

Mg̃M is very predictive and therefore testable: The model has only two free parameters which implies that there are many relations between the masses of the superpartners and Higgses which can be tested experimentally.

Mg̃M has a great cold dark matter candidate: The LSP of Mg̃M is almost a pure Bino for most of the parameter space. This makes the calculation of the relic neutralino (Bino) density relatively easy, because in this scenario neutralino annihilations are dominated by the t-channel exchange of the right-handed sleptons. If one ignores the small (but interesting) region of parameter space where the stau and neutralino are degenerate to within 5%percentPOSTFIX:percent\% (and where co-annihilations are important [22]) the relic neutralino abundance is given by [23]

div.p: This formula is accurate to about 20%percentPOSTFIX:percent\% over the whole parameter space plotted in Figure 2 except for where neutralinos and staus are almost degenerate (a narrow band surrounding the “stau LSP” excluded regions). For Mg̃M Eq. (28) yields abundances which generically are cosmologically safe and often lie within the cosmologically interesting regime 0.1<Ωχ⁢h2<0.30.1subscriptΩ𝜒superscriptℎ20.3NUMBER:0.1 RELOP:less-than Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-chi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0.30.1<\Omega_{\chi}h^{2}<0.3 as is evident from Figure 2.

Mg̃M is theoretically well motivated: Separation of SUSY breaking and the MSSM matter fields onto two different branes naturally gives rise to the Gaugino Mediation boundary condition. If the Higgs fields also live on the MSSM matter brane then all supersymmetry breaking soft Higgs mass parameters vanish, giving Mg̃M. The model is very economical and unifies. We believe that the model is sufficiently “conservative”, successful in solving all the problems of supersymmetry, and elegant that it has a real chance of describing Nature.
